title: Iain Macwhirter  MPs must work together to unblock Brexit  or they   ll open the way for authoritarians
story: So, we at least have breathing space, a pause, a moment for reflection. My own wish would be for MPs to seize the moment and vote to revoke Article  altogether. MPs have the power to stop the clock for good, thanks to the good works of legally-minded MPs like the SNPrsquos Joanna Cherry.Staying in the EU is the only sure way to stop the endless arguments about Canada plus, Norway plus, customs union, Irish backstop, regulatory alignment, maximum facilitation and all the rest of the gubbins thatrsquos been occupying our addled brains for the last two-and-a-half years. However, this isnrsquot going to happen.And Irsquod have to agree that it would be undemocratic for MPs to simply reverse the result of the  referendum by revoking A. It may be that Parliament has the power and the constitutional right to do so: referendums are only advisory. But it would leave so much unpleasantness that British politics would be soured for decades. There would have to be a referendum.This is where my unease turns to genuine anxiety. I have a horrible feeling that Labourrsquos Diane Abbott was right on Question Time this week when she said: ldquoBe careful what you wish for. She agrees with Nigel Farage that a repeat referendum is likely to endorse no-deal Brexit, perhaps by an even greater margin than in .Evenit left us with a mirror-image result, with say % Remain against % Leave, that would itself be a disaster because it would have no legitimacy. Yes, some opinion polls say Remain would win a comfortable majority, but they said that last time.The Brexiteers are already field-testing their slogans on social media. The frontrunner is ldquoTell Them Again, which may not be as resonant as ldquoTake Back Control but is still pretty hot. It surfs on the very widespread disgust and alienation that many ordinary people feel about the political elite. It appeals to democratic injustice: how dare the globalists ignore the result of , which David Cameron promised would be for keeps What would Remainrsquos slogan be  Itrsquos likely to be a repeat of the Project Fear line which failed dismally in . ldquoDonrsquot put your childrenrsquos prosperity at risk, perhaps, or ldquoThink Twice Think Jobs. But what many pro-Europeans fail to grasp ndash and this applied to the Unionists in the Scottish independence referendum ndash is that it ISNrsquoT the economy, stupid. Brexit voters donrsquot just make their decisions on the basis of economic rationality, as seen from the CBI and corporate Britain.People are always motivated more by emotion than numbers ndash on what they believe to be morally right. The sense that working-class people have lost control is a very potent mobiliser.As in war ndash and it is remarkable how much Brexit mythology harks back to World War Two ndash people are quite willing to sacrice some comfort for what they believe in.I may think they are mistaken. As with the people who supported Donald Trump because he promised to Make America Great Again, and bring back the jobs, I think Brexit voters have been sold a  prospectus by politicians who do not have the best interests of working people at their hearts.But that isnrsquot really the point. I can well understand the sense of injustice felt by people who have been left behind by global capitalism. They want to kick the system, and the referendum gave them a chance to do it. They need a very strong reason not to kick the metropolitans again. Only Labour can provide that reason, and Jeremy Corbyn has been singularly reluctant to do so.His refusal even to meet Theresa May was irresponsible in this climate. It may have allowed him to avoid coming off the fence, but it looked petty and weak. Corbyn should have gone in guns blazing, demanded that she drop the red lines, and then mobilised Labour for either rejoining the single market or for a referendum.Single market membership has always been the logic of Labourrsquos position, even though Corbyn usually refers to a ldquopermanent customs union. Only by joining the European Economic Area could Labour deliver friction-free trade, and protect environmental standards and workers rights. People say that Norway has blocked the UKrsquos entry to the European Economic Area, but this is not true. The Norwegian PM, Erna Solberg, has repeatedly made clear that Norway would have severe reservations ndashwho wouldnrsquot  ndash but would not block UK membership.This is because the EEA is essentially a Brussels creation. It was set up as a halfway house to membership of the EU back in  when a number of countries were uneasy about joining the political institutions of Europe. The EEA is just the European Single Market under another name.Brussels endorses British membership of the EEA, and this economic arrangement has a number of advantages over Mayrsquos deal. Therersquos no need for an Irish backstop no membership of the CAP and the Common Fisheries Policy no direct jurisdiction of the European Court and it costs less than EU membership. Of course, it does not bring the full benefits of EU membership. Britain would become a ldquorule taker on trade. But the EEA does not preclude future membership of the European Union. Norway, or any other member of the EEA, can opt for full membership at any time. And unlike the backstop, countries can leave the EEA after one year.Membership of the single market also means accepting freedom of movement, which is why it may well be rejected by Parliament. But it is the only option that has a snowballrsquos chance of getting a majority,Labour were to seriously support it. ldquoNorway plus, as itrsquos called, has more support than a repeat referendum. Fewer than  Labour MPs have called for a Peoples Vote, and only  Conservatives. The SNP has decided to throw its lot in with a repeat referendum, despite having argued convincingly for the single market for the last two years. But that isnrsquot enough.To repeat. Were it left to me, I would revoke Article  tomorrow. I just want this madness to stop. But given the metrics in Parliament, we have to look at the least worst options, as the Labour-supporting commentator Owen Jones put it last week. Mayrsquos deal is dead. MPs owe it to the country, and to themselves, to find some compromise that works. Perhaps that can only be achieved with a referendum. ButMPs fail this week, they risk destroying respect for parliamentary democracy, and opening the way for a more authoritarian form of political leadership.

title: herald-diary-paul-mccartney-cant-dye-me-love
story: BIT icy in Glasgow yesterday. As Stuart Murdoch of Scots indie pop band Belle and Sebastian told fans on social media: "The band are are making their way through ice, fog and cancelled trains just to record for you today. In fact, Dave fell on his arse already, so be careful out there!"And a reader who slipped his way across the citys George Square told us: "It seems the council has brought back the ice rink to George Square a little later this winter. But at least its free."Paws for thoughtNERVOUSLY we have another look at whats happening with Brexit. TV company Hat Trick Productions tells us: "The pet shop chain Pets At Home has revealed it is stockpiling cat food in case of a hard Brexit. The government says itrsquos sensible to fatten them up before we have to eat them."And former Brexit secretary David Davis is to be paid pound, by digger firm JCB for  hours of consultancy work. One or two readers got in touch to say that it was no wonder he got the job as he is an expert at digging a hole that nobody knows how to get out of.Dog licenceTHE Herald reported that % of Scots dont have a TV licence compared to only % in England and Wales. It reminds us of former Prime Minister Gordon Brown once explaining that when he worked at Scottish Television he was told that when folk phoned with complaints, he was to remain courteous but ask them for their TV licence number. Magically, many callers then hung up.And licensing staff once told us that one excuse they received from a viewer without a licence was: "I dont watch it. Its on for my dog. He watches it but Im not paying for him."A bit theatricalTHAT great Scottish actress Maureen Beattie is to appear in a trilogy of plays entitled Interference which will be staged by the National Theatre of Scotland in an unused office suite in the old Wills tobacco factory in Dennistoun. Maureen was once asked by our colleague Brian Beacom when she was not performing, and she replied: "Only when Im asleep." She then gave an example of having an argument with a boyfriend at the time when she was appearing in a play about a couple splitting up. Her then boyfriend halted her harangue to point out to her she was merely repeating lines from the play.Oh, GillyA FINAL Burns Night story before tonights festivities. A Diary chum was recalling a Burns supper at Oran Mor in the west end of Glasgow when actor Gilly Gilchrist had the audience, including  Americans, entranced with his spirited rendition of Rattlin Roarin Willie. The Americans were particularly amazed by the richness of Burns language including the memorable line "Farting wi his piddle". Alas, Gilly had to confess that he had been attempting the correct line, "Parting wi his fiddle" but his tongue got the better of him.Shes toastWE wonder how many folk can identy with stand-up James McNicholas who gave this insight on relationships: "My we unplugs our toaster every time she gets something out of it because shes scared of electricity. So every time I try to toast something, I forget, and put bread in only to come back after two minutes to find untoasted toast and, honestly, I think this might be what ends our marriage."Party timeTODAYS piece of daftness comes from writer Andrew Chamings who says: "Make parties more interesting by telling strangers, I want you to know that I personally have no problem with you being here."To dye forA TABLOID newspaper reported this week that Sir Paul McCartneys hair is now a bright silvery white after he decided to admit his age and stop dying it a, quite frankly, unnatural chestnut colour. Or as a reader explained it to us: "The former Beatles star used to dye, with a little help from his friends, but now its cant dye me love."

title: peoples-vote-supporters-drop-amendment-plan-because-of-lack-of-support-from-labour-leadership
story: Among supporters of the amendment were prominent Labour backbenchers Luciana Berger and Ian Murray and Conservative MP Sarah Wollaston, who chairs the influential Commons Liaison Committee.Ms Berger said: "Because the Labour leadership and frontbench wont back a Peoples Vote, there will not be a vote on the cross-party Peoples Vote amendment next week."This is not good enough. Labour should be clearly setting out a dferent course, not facilitating a job-destroying Brexit," declared the Liverpool MP.Mr Murray, who represents Edinburgh South, told The Herald: ldquoWe are not putting it forward because without the Labour frontbench we donrsquot have the numbers to win it.He stressed how the ldquofirst priority now was to get Article  extended to create the time and space, so that a Peoplersquos Vote could take place. ldquoEvery day people are coming round to the argument for a second vote, insisted Mr Murray.The Labour leader continues to resist calls to throw his partyrsquos formal backing behind the Peoplersquos Vote campaign but has made clear supporting a second EU vote remains ldquoon the tablethe party were unable to force a general election.The Liberal Democrats, meanwhile, have vowed to push ahead with their own amendment calling on the Government to prepare for a second referendum with the option of staying in the EU.Tom Brake, the partyrsquos Brexit spokesman, urged Mr Corbyn to ldquoact in the national interest and back a Peoplersquos Vote.At present, the two amendments attracting most attention are those tabled by Labourrsquos Yvette Cooper and the Conservativesrsquo Andrew Murrison.Ms Cooperrsquos seeks to extend Article  to the end of the yearTheresa May cannot agree a new deal with the EU by February . The aim is to prevent a no-deal Brexit.Whitehall appears to be particularly concerned about this one as it will involve a new bill and so,passed, would be legally binding, which is not the case with the other amendments.If her amendment is successful in next Tuesdayrsquos Commons vote, it is thought Ms Cooper will seek to rush her proposed new bill through the Commons in one day February .However, procedurally, a problem could occur in the Lords, where there is no mechanism to curtail a debate. So, theoretically, peers hostile to the Labour backbencherrsquos proposal could continue talking until such a time that it would cease to have an effectpassed.Mr Murrisonrsquos amendment to time-limit the Irish backstop is expected to be backed by the Government. If passed, it would enable the Prime Minister to go back to Brussels to demand changes as the only way of getting a deal through Parliament, thus avoiding a no-deal outcome.However, it is up to John Bercow, the Speaker, to decide which amendments will be debated and voted on. This will only be known at the start of play on Tuesday.

title: letters-sturgeon-is-grandstanding-on-her-indyref2-claims
story: Is Nicola Sturgeon so confident that she would win another independence referendum  I believe that she is grandstanding in the knowledge the Prime Minister will not give consent.She professes to speak for Scotland. She does not speak for me on his matter and I suspect not for a legion of others.To hold a pseudo referendum, in the absence of that consent, would not only be unconstitutional, but also be a waste of time, money and effort since many opposed would not bother to turn out.Ian W Thomson, Kirkintilloch Road, Lenzie.THERESA May has once more, this time in the House of Commons, ruled out a second independence referendum. Nicola Sturgeon has already made clear she wont risk an illegal Catalan-style vote. Therefore its game over for a referendum before the  Holyrood election, realistically meaning perhaps - ndash and only thena nationalist majority is ed.So will Ms Sturgeon move on from obsessing about the constitution  Will she wholly devote her time to the job we employ her to do ndasheffectively managing Scotlands public services  Or have I had an espresso too many this morning Martin Redfern,Woodcroft Road, Edinburgh.IAIN Macwhirter concludes that for the sake of SNP party unity, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will have to find some kind of accommodation with her predecessor Alex Salmondthey are to successfully pursue independence indyref", The Herald, January . Yetthey truly want to put Scotlandrsquos interests first, both will need to consider just what another isive referendum will do for us.Optimistic separatists might conclude that just a few percentage points stands between them and getting their way. But would that be an end to it  After all the discord and uncertainty suffered so far in trying to undo our relatively recent membership of the EU, what complications and obstacles would stand in the way of a smooth exit from our much closer union with the UK that has lasted hundreds of years Equally,the consistent results of opinion polls are any guide, the likelier outcome would in any case be a repeat of the  result. What then  Surely the SNP, like its counterparts in Quebec back in the mid-s, would suffer the electoral consequences of being viewed as the party which will never take No for an answer.Is it too much to think that one day we could have a Scottish government that seeks a unity of purpose across the political ide in pursuit of Scotlandrsquos positive development, rather than simply finding the most effective grievance upon which to try to get their way Keith Howell,White Moss, West Linton, Peeblesshire.THE First Minister, having legal training and lacking scientic background, may well be unfamiliar with Newtonrsquos Third Law: ldquoTo every action there is an equal but opposite reaction. Dr Gerald Edwardsmakes an oblique reference to Isaac Newton: ldquoitsactions promote equal and opposite reactions.Newtonrsquos work is useful, or potentially so, to physicists and politicians.William Durward, South Erskine Park, Bearsden.DR Gerald Edwardsclaims that the  per cent of voters who voted No at the last independence referendum wont be swayed into voting Yes at the next one. However, Scotland and the UK are in a very dferent place than they were in , and many voters voted to stay in the UK because they were told that was the only way Scotlands place in Europe could be assured. Now that we are being dangled over the edge of the hard Brexit clf, there is no reason why Scotland should be thrown into the abyss and suffer cataclysmic consequences for this and future generations, when we voted overwhelmingly to remain within the EU.Dr Edwards complains about the SNPs record in government, but while there are certainly challenges to be met, Scotland continues to compare well with the rest of the UK for instance,we didnt have the Scottish Parliament and SNP Government, we would be paying pound. per item for our medical prescriptions, and spending thousands of pounds on our childrens university tuition fees, as is the case in England. However,Scottish voters want to put the SNP out of government, they have the power to do so, which is not the case with UK governments where at Westminster, Northern Ireland has  seats, Wales has , Scotland has  and England has , meaning Scotland must always get the governments England elects. With independence, Scotland would always get the governments we voted for, not ones we consistently and comprehensively reject.Ruth Marr, Grampian Road, Stirling.WITH all the brouhaha over Brexit, we in Kilmacolm have decided to set up our own autonomous, independent republic of Kilmacolm, with a hard border in the middle of the Clyde. We welcome immigrants of every size, shape, colour, profession or orientation, but you need to hurry with your applications before Theresa May builds a wall.Margaret Forbes,Corlic Way, Kilmacolm.THE contribution from L McDermottextolling the virtue of any future referendum of having to receive a   endorsement to be successful seems reasonable.However eventhis threshold were to be achieved,the number of voters taking part is only    per cent the result would still be open to challenge. Surely it is now time to consider legislation compelling  per cent of the electorate to either visit the polling station or submit a postal vote. It would be permissible to spoil the paper, but people must take part.I cannot see any downside to this as legitimacy of the result could no longer be challenged.James Martin, Thomson Drive, Bearsden.Read more: Sturgeon accuses May over indyref

title: tunnocks-toasts-25-surge-in-overseas-sales
story: Accounts for Thomas Tunnock newly filed at Companies House show the Lanarkshire firm grew turnover by  per cent to pound. million in the latest financial year, from pound.m in the preceding period.Read more: Tunnocks donation securesof St Abbs leboatTunnockrsquos grew exports by % to around poundm after winning a following in markets ranging from Saudi Arabia to Australia over the years.The companyrsquos octogenarian owner Boyd Tunnock was awarded an MBE  years ago in recognition of its success in overseas markets.Tunnockrsquos may have benefited from the fall in the pound following the Brexit vote in , which has made products priced in sterling cheaper for overseas buyers.The accounts for the year ended February   cover a period during which Tunnockrsquos ramped up capacity at its plant in Uddingston to meet worldwide demand for its products, which include caramel logs and wafers.Read more: Tunnocks hopes wafer cream will be big in JapanIn  Tunnockrsquos commissioned a fourth teacake plant and announced plans for a factory extension.In a statement issued yesterday the company noted: ldquoA self-funded , square feet extension to the factory in Uddingston was completed mid  and is fully operational with additional staff recruited.Tunnockrsquos added: ldquoTrading remains very competitive and sincere thanks is given to customers and employees for their continued loyalty and support.The company did not elaborate.However, in the accounts signed off last week, directors signalled confidence in the prospects for the firm, which was founded by Boyd Tunnockrsquos grandfather in . They said Tunnockrsquos continues to review the possibility of extending the products in its range.The company doubled the total idend paid to shareholders to poundm in the latest year. It provided a boost to the local economy by increasing the average monthly number of employees to  from .Tunnockrsquos recorded pound.m profits before interest and tax in line with the preceding year. The boardroom paybill increased to pound, from pound,.In June Boyd Tunnock found himself in the spotlight after he confirmed he had given a Rolls Royce to Glasgow City Council.Read more: Mystery pound, Rolls-Royce Tory donor revealed as Boyd TunnockPoliticians had criticised the council for accepting the previously anonymous donation amid an increase in nursery fees for parents.Questions were also raised over any potential conflict of interest as some demanded to know who was behind the gt.Expressing surprise at the reaction, Mr Tunnock said he wanted the donation to be a good thing but did not want to take credit for it.ldquoAll sorts of important people come to Glasgow and I thought it would be right to give them a nice experience, he said.ldquoGlasgow always had a Rolls Royce and I was able to give mine to the city so I thought, why not  I really wanted this to be a good thing, but I didnrsquot want any credit for it so I asked the city to keep my name quiet, but Irsquom quite happy for people to know itrsquos me.In  Tunnockrsquos became embroiled in controversy when it was reported to have removed the lion rampant from its teacakesrsquo packaging after running a poster campaign for the ldquoGreat British Teacake.Scottish nationalists called for a boycott of the products.Read more: Tunnocks sales soar following cybernats logo change boycott campaignMr Tunnock noted at the time: ldquoWe could have said Scottish but yoursquore then promoting Scotland. Wersquore British.On its website Tunnocks notes that it bought its first teacake robot in  in a move it said was a huge step forward. The company says it achieved a signicant increase in productivity after replacing its first caramel log robot with a ldquoshiney new one in .UK sales increased by %, to pound.m in the latest financial year.

title: european-union-has-nothing-more-to-give-the-uk-on-the-brexit-deal
story: Bruno Le Maire said it was up to Theresa Mays Government to find a way out of the situation it found itself in, not EU member states.:Ian McConnell: Those Tory brass necks meant we should have seen this Brexit twist comingHe told BBC Radio s Today that there would be "concrete consequences" of leaving without a deal.Speaking from the World Economic Forum in Davos, Mr Le Maire said: "Im afraid we have nothing to give."An agreement is an agreement and the responsibility of Brexit is clearly on the shoulders of the British government, not on the shoulders of the governments of the EU member states."It is up to the British government to find the right way out, not us, the European governments."If there is a need for any further clarications, of course we are always open to clarications."But reopening the deal would mean weeks, months, of new negotiations between the UK and the European member states, that is exactly what we want to avoid."Asked whether it was possible to revisit the Irish backstop within the Withdrawal Agreement, Mr Le Maire added: "It is done. It is done and I think that we have to stick to the deal.:Ian McConnell: Paris metro poster for slapstick British farce evokes Brexit metaphor"I dont want to speculate on internal British policy because it is quite complicated and the UK is a sovereign country, but we dont have to speculate. It is up to the British Government to take its decisions now."Asked about whether no-deal measures taken by the EU would be as bad as some groups have suggested, including border delays between Dover and Calais, Mr Le Maire said: "We are aware that a no-deal situation would have concrete consequences and would force us to take some decisions to reinforce the control at our borders."So, there are many concrete consequences that would be a consequence of a no-deal situation. But we are prepared to do that."Asked to comment on reports that some EU states want rules to be relaxed in the event of a no-deal Brexit to allow UK lorries and aircraft to operate, he added: "You cant be out of the EU and getting all the benefits of the single market. That is a clear red line for France."Chancellor Philip Hammond declined to rule out quittingTheresa May decided to back a no-deal Brexit.Asked repeatedly on Today whether he would remain in the UKs top financial post in that scenario, he said: "Im not going to speculate because a lot depends on the circumstances, what happens."The responsibility I have is to manage the economy in what is the best interests of the British people.Mr Hammond put some distance between himself and MPs including Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd - who has also declined to rule out quitting over no-deal - over the importance of Tuesdays Brexit vote.He told Today: "What Amber is doing is reflecting a view among some of my colleagues that somehow next Tuesday is high noon, the last chance to make a stand against no-deal."I dont think that is the case, I dont think next Tuesday has to be, or indeed will be the high noon of this debate."Parliament will want to be confident that it will have an opportunity to express its clear view and some of my colleagues, including some who are in Government, will want to be able to express their view."But I dont think next Tuesday is the point when this comes to a head."Mr Hammond showed the depth of the row inside the Cabinet over a no-deal Brexit, doubling down on his warnings about the damage it would cause to the economy.He told Today: "What people were told in the referendum campaign, the majority who voted to leave, they were told that we would be able to get a deal with the European Union, that that would protect our jobs and our prosperity and that our exit could be smooth and orderly to a new relationship with the European Union."But it is absolutely clear thatwe dont get a deal that is not the way it will work."There will be very signicant disruption in the short term and a very signicant hit to our economy in the medium to long term."Our job is to deliver the British people what they believe they were promised in that referendum, to make sure we respect the decision of the referendum but do it in a way that gives them the future prosperity they were promised."Mr Hammond added: "Thedisruption that we would expect would happen around the no-deal exit will be short term."It will settle down, we will find ways of managing things like the additional time it takes for trucks to get through the border."But it might take us quite a while to sort that out. So there will be a short-term impact through disruption, there will be a long-term impact through a reduction in the size of our economy."That is not what people voted for. People did not vote to be worse off, they voted to be better off and they were told that was possible and it is our job to try to deliver on that for them."

title: celtic-connections-review-patrick-doyle-a-celebration-city-halls-glasgow
story: Patrick Doyle: A CelebrationCity Halls, GlasgowKeith Brucefour starsCOMPOSER Patrick Doyle is a natural hyperbolist, whose superlatives can lead him into troubled waters, and as his own master of ceremonies for this celebration of his music, he was visibly keeping his tendency to be erted mid-story in check, although few folk name-drop with such ebullient charm.There was a lot of music to get through, however, and the contribution of conductor Dirk Brosse to the seamless success of this evening ndash as well as the masterful musicianship of the BBC SSO ndash cannot be overstated.The musical highlight of the night was the performance of the Pumpkin Pursuit from Doylersquos score for Cinderella, a truly dramatic and dynamic piece of writing that was the best evidence of how Brosse was able to galvanise the whole orchestra after many of them had been relatively idle for a while.The strings put in a full sht nonetheless, orchestra leader Laura Samuel shone on Corarsik, a piece for violin soloist originally written as birthday gt for Emma Thompson, while first cello Sian Bell had an equal share of the spotlight.In its full glare, however, were the vocal soloists, Mairi MacInnes on the cue from the recent remake of Whisky Galore, acting student from the University of the West of Scotland Eva Walker hamming it up to a band playing with Sigh No More from Much Ado About Nothing, and Doylersquos daughters Abigail and Nuala with Tir Na Nog from Into the West and Never Forget from Murder on the Orient Express, both of whom showed how the musical gene is thriving in the family.The Doyle heritage was represented too, in a recording of the composerrsquos father restored from the family archive and given live orchestral accompaniment, in a piece of understated but impressive technical wizardry that would, as they say, have brought a tear to a glass eye.With the Phoenix Choir adding the choral element and top traditional musicians Fraser Field, Jarlath Henderson and Chris Stout contributing their considerable skills, Doyle kept his best trick for the end. His new Scottish Overture featured piper Lorne MacDougall making his entrance from the back of the hall, and is a piece that ticks all the boxes and press all the buttons. We heard the world premiere, but nothing is more certain than that we shall be hearing it again.

title: mieles-gelaterias-worlds-first-burns-supper-ice-cream
story: Family-run Mieles Gelateria has taken the traditional Scots dish of haggis, neeps and tatties, and combined them in the ultimate cold dessert.And customers can enjoy the spicy meat flavour in a tub or atop a wafer cone, with a warm dollop of whisky cream sauce to finish.Michael Mieles who runs the Highland parlour alongside brother David and father Robertosays coming up with crazy creations is the best part of the job.The team at Meiles love creating flavours."When I was initially setting up the company a few years ago, I used to talk to chefs about my ideas" he said."Wed genuinely just sit and laugh at how weird some of them were."The gelateria, which has been operating for just over two years, released the popular Scottish concoction in time for Burns Day.Read more:Alternative ways to enjoy haggis this Burns Night"People are so intrigued with how weird it is," says Michael. "I think people come just so theyll be able to say theyve tried it."Itrsquos like marmite ndash some people absolutely love it, but the best reactions are when people screw their faces up."Customers are first hit with the home-made mashed potato, which brings forth hints of garlic and a creamy texture.The turnip comes next, albeit not with as powerful a taste as the vegetable does on its own.And finally, the spiciness of the haggis breaks through, sourced frompopular Inverness butchers Duncan Frasers - the best butcher in town, according to Michael."It plays with your head," he chuckles. "Youre eating something that you expect to be very sweet, but when you taste it, its anything but."The treat is then topped with a warm whisky sauce, which is made with half a bottle of "The One", a -year-old drink locally sourced fromWoodwinters.It isnt the first time Mieles has combined savoury treats with ice cream last year, their homage to Pancake Tuesday proved popular, with their maple syrup and bacon flavoured gelato going down a treat.They have so far created over  dferent flavours, and have no plans to stop.Theyve created over  flavours."A lot of people like the idea of batter flavour mixed with ice cream," says Michael, "It gives people a memory of when they were a kid and baking at home with their parents, like licking the bowl or the wooden spoon."Wereall about nostalgia."The team can often be found traipsing through retro sweet shops, searching for inspiration for their next creation.Read more:Scotlandrsquos  best places to get an ice creamWhen they arent delving into the world of chocolate, they find that alcohol-inspired gelato is always a hit.So far, theyve experimented with dferent whisky, beers, and even Blue WKD - and have no plans to stop there."Winter is the best because it gives us a chance to get our heads down and have fun in the factory," Michael explained."Customers will constantly come to us with ideas, and we always try our best to meet their expectations."But Michael admits that the idea for a Burns Supper gelato was of his own valition: "This was my own madness ndash I canrsquot blame anyone  for this one."The team posted a video of the creation to their Facebook page, racking up thousands of likes and many dfering opinions in the comments.The video follows the trail of ingredients, first stopping off at the butchers, then to get the whisky, and finally ending in Mieles Geletaria, where the finished creation takes pride of place in the freezer.The parlour won Best Geletaria in Scotland in the  Scottish Italian Awards, which recognise the best Italian eateries across the country.

title: uk-ministers-praise-queens-for-wise-words-on-seeking-common-ground-as-politicians-struggle-over-brexit
story: Speaking at an event in Sandringham, Her Majesty extolled the virtues of "respecting" the other persons point of view.Philip Hammond hailed her remarks, saying: ldquoThere is huge wisdom in those words and I dont think anybody will be at all surprised to hear the Queen advocating the view that in all things controversial we should seek compromise, we should seek common ground and we should seek a way forward."That is actually what we do in this country, that is how we solve problems, by compromise and pragmatism, explained the Chancellor."Its been our enormous strength over centuries that we have been able to find compromises that bring the nation together," he told BBC Radio Fourrsquos Today programme.His Cabinet colleague Amber Rudd, the Work and Pensions Secretary, tweeted: "Wise words from the Queen," while Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, also took to social media to declare: "I agree with the Queen."Theresa Mays spokesman declined to comment directly on the Queens remarks, but told reporters: "The Prime Ministers own view is that we should always show great respect for the point of view of others."As head of state, the Queen remains publicly neutral when it comes to political matters and does not explicitly express her views on issues.However, the last time she was regarded as having made a major intervention into politics occurred in  before the Scottish independence referendum when she told a well-wisher at Balmoral: ldquoWell, I hope people will think very carefully about the future. This was widely seen as urging Scotland to vote No and remain part of the UK.The Queen made her comments in a speech to mark the centenary of the Sandringham Womens Institute, of which she is President.She said: "Reflecting on a century of change, it is clear that the qualities of the WI endure. The continued emphasis on patience, friendship, a strong community focus, and considering the needs of others, are as important today as they were when the group was founded all those years ago."Of course, every generation faces fresh challenges and opportunities."As we look for new answers in the modern age, I for one prefer the tried and tested recipes, like speaking well of each other and respecting dferent points of view coming together to seek out the common ground and never losing sight of the bigger picture."To me, these approaches are timeless, and I commend them to everyone," Her Majesty added.In her Christmas address the Queen touched on the same theme, telling the nation: "Even with the most deeply held dferences, treating the other person with respect and as a fellow human being is always a good first step towards greater understanding."

title: universal-credit-leaving-veterans-suicidal-says-scottish-minister
story: Graeme Dey believes ex-servicemen and women claiming under the new benefit regime face particular challenges due to their military service, including being more likely to have a reduced income.:Universal credit contributing to pound. million in council house rent arrears claims East Ayrshire councillorThe Veterans Minister said charities including Erskine, Blesma and Scotlands Bravest Manufacturing Company raised concerns about the impact of Universal Credit.In a letter to Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd and Defence Minister Tobias Elwood, Mr Dey said: "Unfortunately, the lack of dedicated support for veterans and the in-built inflexibility within UC has been a contributing factor in several shocking and tragic case studies, and the veterans charities have reported that there are cases where veterans have been left suicidal."The charities have gone above and beyond their remits to support these iniduals but they are concerned about what the future holds as many more veterans migrate on to UC as a result of a change in circumstances."He added: "Veterans seeking to adjust to civilian le are more likely to undergo changes of circumstances as they resettle and the natural migration to UC that this will result in risks causing additional upheaval for them at a time when they most need support.:Call to halt disastrous Universal Credit roll-out as millions face losing pound a week"This is also likely to result in a reduced income as those migrating naturally will not be eligible to receive transitional protection."Mr Dey said veterans may be suffering from physical disabilities or mental illness and the charities suggested those they help in some cases have poorer literacy skills.He said: "The requirement for all UC applications to be completed online is therefore challenging for many."The application process also requires a large amount of information, which may not be readily accessible, especially for early service leavers or those who have been discharged due to disability."He called for assistance for veterans at the start of the claims process and said ignoring the problems "would risk failing in our joint commitment to members of the armed forces community".Mr Dey urged the Department for Work and Pensionsto have forces and veterans champions in Job Centre help veterans access appropriate support.A DWP spokesperson said: "We value our armed services and veterans."Universal Credit provides veterans and their families with a range of specialised support through the Armed Forces Covenant, there is an armed forces champion in every district and Jobcentre staff work closely with charities, such as the Royal British Legion."

title: councils-back-improved-offer-for-teachers-in-bid-to-halt-strikes
story: The profession has been offered nine per cent over three years as well as extra cash to restructure pay scales worth around  per cent overall.However, the ruling council of the Educational Institute of Scotlandvoted narrowly to advisemembers not to accept the joint offer from the Scottish Government and council umbrella body Cosla.Although the proposal was rejected - by  votes to  after a two hour debate - it will still be up to teachers to decide whether to accept it.The EIS has demanded a ten per cent rise to address a decade of pay erosion, but councils argue they cannot afford such an increase.The EIS said a consultative ballot of members will now be held on the offer, with a separate ballot on strike action suspended.The EIS said its council would recommend a rejectoin of the deal, but that members should be told both arguments for and against the offer.Larry Flanagan, EIS general secretary, said: "Following todayrsquos decision at council, it will now be for our members to decide on whether to accept or reject this revised offer.Gail Macgregor, education spokeswoman for Cosla, expressed concern over the vote.Earlier in the day at a meeting in Edinburgh, Cosla had agreed to backthe enhanced offer from the Scottish Government.She said: "This is disappointing. We have absolutely gone as far as we can and hopefully teachers accept what is a very good deal."We understand the teachers unions will now present this revised and enhanced offer to their members and we would strongly encourage its acceptance."The offer means a three per cent pay increase in   for all grades up to a cap of pound, with a flat rate increase of pound, for salaries above that level.There will also be a three per cent in   for all posts with a similar arrangement for the following year.In recognition of concern over problems in the recruitment and retention of teachers Cosla has also agreed to back a restructuringof wider pay scales and took at pay for promoted teachers.

title: charity to mark 140th anniversary with celebratory ball
story: Local charity North East Sensory Services will mark  years of improving lives with a celebratory Ball to remember.The charity operates with the main aim of achieving independence for blind and deaf people.The prestigious Ball event will take place at Aberdeens five-star Marclfe Hotel on Friday, March .A wonderful line-up of entertainment will be topped with a live performance set from singer, radio and television presenter, Aled Jones MBE.Aled has been a household name since the s, and will be forever noted as having been one of the worlds most successful boy sopranos.He is best known for singing Walking in the Air in the animated film, The Snowman.His theatre work is world famous too, having enjoyed starring roles including Joseph in Andrew Lloyd Webbers Joseph and the Amazing Technicolour Dreamcoat.The Ball event will be hosted by Emmerdale favourite Chris Chittell, best known for his role as Eric Pollard in the ITV soap.Entertainment will also be provided by top class live band Callanish.Stronachs are kindly sponsoring the champaign reception at the event.A spokesperson for the law firm said: "Stronachs are delighted to be associated with this long established charity and the services they provide to the blind and deaf communities, and are looking forward to being part of a fantastic launch event."Tickets for the Ball are still available for those who would like to join the guest list. title: house plan approved at oldmeldrum
story: The future of Oldmeldrum Golf Club has been secured thanks to councillors at the Formartine Area Committee.Plans to build a single house on land at the golf course went before councillors on Tuesday, January .The site in question is located directly behind an existing house next to the A and A junction.It is currently used for turf growing, but it had been classed as “obsolete” as it is cheaper for the Golf Club to buy new turfcompared to the man hours needed to maintain and cut their own.The planning application received a total of  representations, all of which were in support of the idea.However in a report put to councillors ahead of the meeting, council planners recommended that the plan be refused as the land had never been developed, and that the development itself was contrary to policy in the Aberdeenshire Local Development Plan.Speaking at the meeting on behalf of the club, Patricia Ramsay said that it is currently facing financial dficulties and the debt that it has is preventing the club from moving forward.She added: “The sale of this unused piece of land is the only way of raising much needed funds.“This would be a leline to this community asset.”After discussing the plan, councillor Paul Johnston suggested that the plans be approved with a delegated grant, and his decision was backed by councillor Karen Adam.Cllr Johnston said: “We have to think about the public circumstances, this is a private club but should it have to wind up, that would have a knock-on effect in the local community.”The proposal went to a vote and seven councillors backed the plan with just one vote against it.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: ice cream parlour to go orange for charity
story: Mackie#s of Scotland will colour their most popular flavour, known as #Traditional#, bright orange on Friday, February , to raise awareness and money for charity.Mackie’s ., their Aberdeen ice cream parlour, will be a bright vision with orange lighting, balloons and staff dressed in orange T-shirts for Muscular Dystrophy UK.Even the company’s logo will be converted to an orange spotted cow for the day. Alongside the orange Traditional ice cream, a parlour cabinet will be filled with over  orange tubs, each containing one of nine dferent prizes, from £ gt vouchers, to chocolate bars, so that customers can take part in a fundraising lucky dip.Mackie’s Marketing Director, Karin Hayhow said: “Muscular Dystrophy UK is a charity close to our hearts because we have experienced first-hand the severity of the illness.“We hope that our parlour customers have fun with the orange lucky dip infor a donation towards the work of Muscular Dystrophy UK.”The company is getting behind the day as part of their long-running support for people with any type of muscular dystrophy in Scotland.Muscular Dystrophy UK is the official charity for Mackie’s of Scotland and the joint venture company, Mackie’s at Taypack who make Mackie’s potato crisps and other savoury snacks.The association is founded on the personal experience of both companies, as Denis Emslie who worked as the Sales Director at Mackie’s of Scotland for  years, and Mark Taylor - brother of George Taylor, Managing Director at Mackie’s at Taypack - both lost their lives to forms of MD.Scotland’s Muscular Dystrophy UK Regional Development Manager, Dean Widd said: “We are incredibly grateful to our wonderful corporate partners Mackie’s of Scotland. There are just over , people in Scotland with muscular dystrophy and the money raised through Go Orange for a Day helps to fund our work into new treatments and campaigns for better care and support for people with muscle wasting conditions to live as independently as possible.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.deesidepiper webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

story: Plans have been unveiled for a socially-inclusive soft play centre at an Inverurie industrial estate.Newly-formed charity ‘Because Everyone Counts’ wants to create the facility at a unit owned by Craigdon Mountain Sports at Burghmuir Circle.The group has been founded to provide a safe and inclusive play space for children from the local community from pre-school and nursery school age up to a maximum of  years.The applicants say the facility will be the first inclusive soft play centre within the North-east to offer adapted play to allow those with additional support needs to integrate with mainstream children.In a supporting statement to Aberdeenshire Council’s planning department, they say: “It will work together with local groups and schools such as St. Andrews offering somewhere safe to go.”A separate room will be available for children with limited communication and sensory disorders and will provide multi-sensory equipment.The facility would operate from .am to .pm seven days a week and the expected usage will be for a maximum of  children per day split into two-hour sessions.It is understood that special needs groups will arrive and be collected by mini-bus as will groups from local nurseries.If successful, the soft play centre would take up residence next to the Inverurie Gymnastics Club which also leases a unit.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: mackie s offers sweet take on burns night scran
story: Back by popular demand, Mackies of Scotland is relaunching its limited edition haggis and marmalade ice cream for Burns Night.The handcrafted speciality recipe – which has been made on the firms Westertown family farm – is available all weekend at Mackie’s . parlour in Aberdeen.The Burns Night treat will be available all weekendAt am this morning, piper Robert Reid from Deeside Caledonia Pipe Band piped the haggis ice cream in to the Marischal Square parlour.The ice cream has been made with Scotland’s famous Hall’s haggis, and has orange marmalade swirled through the mix.In celebration of Scotland’s Ploughman Poet, customers at . will be given free samples of the experimental dessert – and those who play a tune on the bagpipes will be able to enjoy any free scoop of their choice.Yvette Harrison, Parlour Manager at Mackie’s ., said: “While Marmalade is not a traditional accompaniment for Haggis – we added a ripple to help make this Scottish delicacy a little tastier when served cold in ice cream. And, of course a nip of whisky can also be drizzled over the top to raise a cone to the Bard.“Our haggis ice cream was such a hit last year that we just had to bring it back for Burns Night . Since last year’s limited edition batch, we’ve had people visit the parlour specically to try the flavour. So this weekend is the perfect opportunity for those who didn’t get the chance the first time round to satisfy their curiosity – and their taste buds.”Mackie’s is encouraging the public to share their thoughts on the creation with the hashtag #taemackiesicecream.Yvette added: “We love experimenting with our flavours at Mackie’s, and in celebration of Burns we’re challenging everyone to step outside their comfort zone, and try a scoop of our latest creation."data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Singer, radio and television presenter Aled Jones MBE will perform a live set at the event"  Charity to mark th anniversary with celebratory Ball viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: top quality entries set to take part in the royal northern spring show
story: Entries are up on the year for next month#s annual multi-breed show and sale of pedigree bulls staged alongside the Royal Northern Spring Show at Thainstone.The sale, to be held on Wednesday, February , has attracted  entries from breeders across the north and north-east, and will include Aberdeen-Angus, Charolais, Limousins, Simmentals, Salers, Herefords, Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue.Last year’s sale saw a top price and a new centre record of ,gns paid for a Simmental bull from the MacPherson family at Blackford, Croy. This was Blackford Hero, by the ,gns Kilbride Farm Double Action, which sold across the water to a breeder in Northern Ireland. The MacPhersons have entered two Simmental bulls for next month’s sale, one of which was bought as a calf at foot from the Deerhurst dispersal and is by the ,gns Blackford Findhorn. The other bull from Blackford is one of the first sons of Blackford Galaxy.At the same sale last year, Charolais bulls produced the second lead price of gns for one from Charles McCombie and family of Auchincrieve, Rothiemay, near Huntly. The same home has entered three Charolais bulls this year, as well as one Aberdeen-Angus bull.Top price in the Aberdeen-Angus section at ’s sale was gns paid for a bull from father and son team, Neil and Mark Wattie, Mains of Tonley, near Alford. Tonley has entered three Aberdeen-Angus bulls for this year’s sale.Among the Limousins last year, the overall champion in the pre-sale show from Harry and Lynwen Emslie, Kinknockie, Mintlaw, topped at gns. Reserve was another Limousin from Andrew Gammie, Drumforber, Laurencekirk, which made gns. In all, this year’s bull entries stand at  Aberdeen-Angus,  Charolais,  Limousins,  Simmentals, eight Salers, two Herefords, two Beef Shorthorns and one British Blue. Two pedigree Limousin females have also been entered for the sale. John Angus, Head of Livestock for Aberdeen and Northern Marts, said: “We have a strong entry of quality bulls forward again this year and prices paid in the past for bulls demonstrates the standard of stock brought forward."This sale is a great opportunity for breeders to acquire top class bulls from established breeders in the area.”data-src"https:res. jpress image fetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Banff and Buchan MP David Duguid"  MP tables amendment to Fisheries Bill on CFP exit date viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: women urged to go for smear after uptake reaches all time low
story: A north east MSP is encouraging women to go for their smear test to help reduce their risk of cervical cancer after it was revealed uptake is at an all time low.It comes as the charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust aims to raise awareness during Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.More than , women are diagnosed with cervical cancer every year in the UK.Cervical screeningare the best protection against the disease, followed by the HPV vaccine offered in schools.Figures have revealed that last year, cervical screening uptake in Scotland fell from .% to .% meaning that more than one in four eligible women missed their screen test.This week Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust has published new research which has found young women who delay or don’t go for cervical screening feel scared , vulnerableand embarrassedat the thought of going.A worrying two thirdssay they would not feel in control at the prospect of a test.Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin said: “I am delighted to be working with Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust this Cervical Cancer Prevention Week.“Cervical screening prevents up to % of cervical cancers developing, so it is worrying to hear that so many women are not attending this test when invited, particularly due to embarrassment.“It’s a small test which can make a huge dference so I would urge women to encourage daughters, nieces, other family and friends who are eligible for the test to do so.”Robert Music, Chief Executive of Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust said: “We are delighted to have Gillian Martin’s support to help raise awareness about the importance of cervical screening.Smear tests provide the best protection against cervical cancer yet we know they aren’t always easy.“We want women to feel comfortable talking to their nurse and asking questions. It’s not making a fuss and there are many ways to make the test easier. Please don’t let your fears stop you booking a test.” data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Police Scotland"  Two taken to hospital after crash viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: workshop to develop artwork ideas for new kintore rail station
story: A day of workshops to develop ideas for potential future artwork at the new Kintore Rail Station will take place on Saturday .People living in the town and surrounding communities are invited to take part in the event, which will run from .am to .pm in Kintore Church Hall.Anyone who wants to be involved, but without taking part in the workshop sessions, is welcome to simply drop-in throughout the day.Studio Niro, a multidisciplinary design practice, is organising the event in collaboration with Aberdeenshire Council. The workshops will involve colour mixing and print making to create a library of Kintore colours and shapes which will then be used to develop artwork.The sessions will take place from .am-pm and from -.pm and members of the community are asked to bring along a camera and any old photos of Kintore they may have. Free tickets can be booked at www.krsartwork.eventbrite or by calling   . The new railway station is part of the wider Aberdeen to Inverness Improvement Project .A representative from Network Rail will be available during the day to provide information on the project and forthcoming related works in .The workshops also provide the opportunity to re-unite for the first time in at least fty years two benches installed at the original Kintore Station, which was closed in the late s.Prior to their restoration, both benches will be on display for members of public to see. Visitors will be invited to take “selfies” with the hashtag #kintorebenches to show their support for the project.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The new facility would be located at Burghmuir Circle"  Inverurie play centre plans unveiled viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Friday  Jan  : PM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Friday  Jan  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Jan  : PM

title: Sir Chris top peak is Suilven
story: HE has conquered Everest and is considered Britains greatest living mountaineer.But climbing luminary Sir Chris Bonington has told top travel guide Wanderlust that Suilven in north-west Sutherland is the mountain that most shaped his le.Sir Chriss career has included  expeditions to the Himalayas, including four to the worlds highest mountain, and the first ascent of the south face of Annapurna.The mountain was immortalised last year in the film Edie, in which Sheila Hancock stars as an octogenarian who makes a le-changing decision to climb its steep, remote slopes.Sir Chrissaid: "Suilven is a long whale-back of a mountain, but when you approach it from the west you just see the end of it ndash an absolutely perfect peak, with a great sandstone buttress."I first climbed Suilven when I was  and it is one of the most magical days I have ever had."It was my second holiday in Scotland, just after I had discovered climbing, and I went up with a friend. We carried our rucksacks, hitch-hiked, and bivvied most of the time. I remember sleeping in the ruins of Ardvreck Castle ndash it was the only thing with a roof on it for miles ndash before we set off from Lochinver to climb Suilven."We tried following a route which wasnt very good, so we ended up climbing a new route."The views from the top of Suilven were incredible. To the south there was a big, wide loch, dotted with islands."That day captured everything that I love about climbing and inspired me to keep doing it ndash the sense of exploration, the beauty of the mountains themselves, as well as the experience of really stretching yourself in the process."Second on his list was the North Face of the Eiger, ahead of the Central Tower of Paine, Chile.The Old Man of Hoy, Orkneys ft sea-stack, was placed fourth on his list. Sir Chris made the first ascent of the Old Man of Hoy in  and climbed it again in ."I was the first person to climb the Old Man of Hoy and the oldest when I climbed it again when I was ," Sir Chris said.Friday  Jan  : PM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Friday  Jan  : PM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeFriday  Jan  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Friday  Jan  : PM

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. title: invitation to tender issued for northern isles ferry contract
story: An Invitation to Tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services has been issued to three bidders, the Scottish Government announced today, Thursday.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July.The contract is estimated to be worth £m and will run for eight years. The names of the companies involved have however, not been released.Minister for energy, connectivity and the islands, Paul Wheelhouse, said: “Issuing the Invitation to Tender marks the next stage of the process to award the new contract to operate the Northern Isles Ferry Services.“The contract will run for eight years, allowing us to build a strong working relationship with the successful bidder, and all the routes within the network are being tendered as a single bundle.“The Scottish Government remains fully committed to high quality ferry services to the Northern Isles. A key benefit of this new contract is the in-built flexibility, allowing the ferry services to be amended to reflect future changes in demand across the important sectors of the islands’ economies – tourism, fishing, food and drink, aquaculture and farming. Scottish Ministers will also retain control of all of important issues, such as fares and timetables, through the public service contract.“We are committed to a fair, open and transparent tender which aims to get the best possible deal for the communities that depend on these ferry services.”• Commenting on the issue, Northern Isles MSP’s Liam McArthur and Tavish Scott said: “The Scottish Government have finally issued the tender. The timescale is very tight indeed given the operator needs to be up and running the North Isles leline ferry services in  months’ time. It is essential that companies make constructive bids with improvements to the existing service. It must, in particular, recognise the growing freight volumes that are being exported south to the Scottish mainland.“So the tender bids must be properly assessed to ensure the service moves forward and not backwards. And the endless saga of RET must come to an end, otherwise how can bidding companies submit a proposed fare policy ”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
